p: M. Asadi is currently an Associate Professor at the Department of Statistics, University of Isfahan, Isfahan, Iran. He received the B.S. degree in 1989 and M.S. in 1992 both in statistics from university of Mashhad, Iran. He received the PhD degree in statistics from University of Sheffield, Sheffield, UK, in 1999. His research interests include reliability theory, information theory, ordered random variables, and characterization of probability distributions.

details.abstract: We consider a coherent structure consisting of n components having the property that if it is known that at most r components (r < n) have failed, the system is still operating with probability 1. Some examples of the systems having this property are (n - k + 1)-out-of- n, some parallel-series, and some series-parallel structures. Depending on the structure, and the number of active components of the coherent systems at time t , the mean residual life function of the system is studied, by several authors. This paper investigates more properties of the mean residual life function of the coherent systems sharing the described property. We will show that, when the components of the system have increasing failure rate, the mean residual life function of the system is decreasing in time. Several examples, and illustrative graphs are also provided.

links.abstract: In the study of the reliability of technical systems, k-out-of-n systems play an important role. In the present paper, we consider a k-out-of-n system consisting of n identical components with independent lifetimes having a common distribution function F. Under the condition that, at time t, all the components of the system are working, we propose a new definition for the mean residual life (MRL) function of the system, and obtain several properties of that system.

context.text: Asadi & Bayramoglu [2] considered the residual random variable \$T_{t}^{1,k,n}\$, \$k=1,\ldots,n\$ which is the residual lifetime of a \$(n-k+1)\$-out-of-\$n\$ system in which, at time \$t\$, all components of the system are operating.
Asadi & Bayramoglu [2] show that, when the components of the system are IFR (decreasing failure rate (DFR)), then \$H_{n}^{k}(t)\$ is decreasing (increasing) in time.
Asadi & Bayramoglu [2] have shown that, when the components of a \$(n-k+1)\$-out-of-\$n\$ system are IFR (DFR), then the MRL \$H_{n}^{k}(t)\$ is a decreasing (increasing) function of time.

Asadi & Bayramoglu [2] have shown that the MRL \$H_{n}^{k}(t)\$ for GPD has the form Based on the above corollary, if the components of a coherent system are distributed as GPD, then the MRL of the system is bounded above by the linear function of time A similar expression can be obtained for the lower bound of the system.

links.abstract: This paper shows that: (1) the mean residual life (MRL) of a component has an upside-down bathtub-shape if the component has a bathtub-shape failure-rate function, but the converse does not hold; and (2) there is an optimal burn-in policy to maximize the MRL when the underlying lifetime distribution has a bathtub-shape failure rate.

context.text: It is well known that a distribution function with bathtub failure rate has upside-down bathtub MRL function (see, for example, Mi [10]).

links.abstract: A representation is derived for the failure rate of an arbitrary s-coherent system when the lifetimes of its components are s-independently distributed according to a common absolutely continuous distribution F. The system failure rate is written explicitly as a function of F and its failure rate. The representation is used in several examples, including an example showing that the closure theorem for k-out-of-n systems in i.i.d. context.text: The latter authors noticed, using the concept of signature introduced by Samaniego [12], that the conditional lifetime of a coherent system with the property described above, can be expressed as a convex combination of residual lifetimes of the form \$T_{t}^{r,k,n}\$.

An interesting result of Samaniego [12] shows that the distribution function of the lifetime of a coherent system can be represented as a mixture of the distribution functions of the order statistics \$Z_{1:n},Z_{2:n},\ldots,Z_{n:n}\$ of the \$Z_{i}\$.

More precisely, Samaniego [12] (see also Kochar et al. [8]), introduced the concept of the signature of \$\tau\$ as the probability vector \${\bf p}=(p_{1},p_{2},\ldots,p_{n})\$ where One can show that \$p_{i}=n_{i}/n!\$, in which \$n_{i}\$ is the number of ways that distinct \$Z_{1},Z_{2},\ldots,Z_{n}\$ can be ordered such that \$\tau(z_{1},z_{2},\ldots,z_{n})=z_{i:n}\$, \$i=1,\ldots,n\$, where \$z_{i:n}\$ is the value of \$Z_{i:n}\$.
